segments.text: Today's interview is with James Harvey Kattis, retired associate professor of mechanical engineering at Texas A&M University.
Today's date is August 2, 1982.
Let's begin, Professor Kattis, by you telling us something about your early years.
Where were you born?
Oh, I was born in the town of Winona, Mississippi.
Where is that?
That's in the north central part of Mississippi, about 100 miles north of Jackson, right in the middle of the state.
What year were you born?
What was your father's occupation?
My father's occupation, he was a farmer, he was a railroad woman, he was a
night watchman and he spent his last years running a little store.

He had a little one-horse store and about three miles out from town he conceived that that was a good place for a store and he opened up a store there and ran it for about 27 years till he was some 83 years old and had to give it up.
What was the population of Winona back in the 20s when you were a child?
About 3,000.
What about your mother?
Did she work or was she a housewife?
She was a housewife.
Did you graduate from high school in Winona?
Yes.
How did you get from Winona to Texas A&M?
Oh, I hitchhiked.
What caused you to decide to come to Texas A&M?
I'd heard about it, and then I had the option of going to Mississippi State, which is in Starksville, which is in Mississippi A&M.
And student labor was for 15 cents an hour there.
Over here, it was 25 cents an hour.
Why did you decide to study engineering?
I had always been mechanically inclined and I had worked one summer in an ice plant in my hometown and I liked to see machinery run and like to take over things and make them run.
What year did you graduate from high school?
And you came then to A&M and graduated with a bachelor's degree in 1932.
That's correct.
You stayed here four years.
Right.
You were in the Corps at the time.
Right.
Which was mandatory.
Right.
What were your impressions of being in the Corps at this?
Oh, it was quite a normal thing.
I took a pride in it, got a reserve commission out of it, and...
I recommend it to anybody right now.
What were some of the experiences that you had here at Texas A&M as a student down at graduate level?
What were some of the highlights of your time?
One of the highlights of my time here was that I remember the work I did
on the side, much more really than I do the course work.
The course work, I was able to take in stride and not get behind on it.
And that 25 cents an hour helped keep my head and soul intact.
What was something you had to do?
Oh, I had to put in the foundry.
I had to put in the, what do you call it, the steam lab over there.
The mechanical engineering shop building was new in those days.
After we got through building on those, the original installation and everything was in operation.
Then I got to doing cabin network.
Of course, a little while earlier, I'd done a little plumbing work, too.
While you were here working on your master's degree, you had a great impression of the city.
What were your impressions of the area?

Well, you took it in stride, but when I graduated, the only way in 1932, the only way you wanted to get a job was to have a pull like your father was on the board of directors of some company or something of the sort.
You didn't get just ordinary jobs.
I was one that was selected by the General Electric Company for a job, but they said, we just put you on hold.
We can't put you to work right now.
And there they meant it.
Instead of putting some to work, they let off some safety one
Young engineers that had been with them one or two years up in Schenectady, where I would have worked.
Later they did offer me a job, but I was otherwise employed.
When you were a senior at A&M in 1932, were there any recruiters who came on campus?
No.
Not like later times?
No.
No recruiters.
You'd go out and hunt a job.
Did many of the people in your class have difficulty finding jobs as engineers?
All of them did.
The only way a fella could get a job then was to have a pull, to have somebody who was in a supervisory capacity and could put you in.
What did most of the students do when they couldn't find jobs as engineers?
I had one student who, in the name of Porter, that went back to
His hometown of Belkin started running the billing station.
He was working in the billing station.
Later on, he became the owner of the billing station or the contract mobile station.
Later on, he was mayor of the town and a good many other things.
I've lost track of him, but I had another one by the name of Charlie Young.
He went back and did the same old sort of thing in the town of Kyle and ended up with
As a contractor at a hardware store, they did what they had to.
They did what they should do.
What did you decide to do after your graduation?
Oh, that summer I went up and I was going to get...
General Electric put me to work at some capacity, so long as I keep body and soul intact, I want to go to work and get some experience.
But when I got up to Schenectady, I hitchhiked up there.
I found that they just laid off those 71 young engineers that had been there just ahead of us.
Any number of those would have stayed under the same conditions that I would have gone to work for them.
So, no job then.
But I lucked into a job as an athletic director, bus driver on General Flunky and a girl's camp in Peterborough, New Hampshire.
And I spent that summer in Peterborough, New Hampshire.
Well, yes.
I stayed there eight weeks.
And I made enough money to buy me a motorcycle.
And I took a shortcut on up to Quebec and St. Anne de Beaupr and on up the river there and came back down through Vermont.
back down to New York, Washington, going back home.
And I got a temporary job in my hometown, and after so long a time, I got an offer from Professor Crawford, who was head of mechanical engineering, to come back over.
I thought he'd get me into the graduate assistant.
Well, I came over considerably early.
And I went back to my job of doing cabinet work.
What did you start as a director, Susan?
In the fall of 1933.
Professor Crawford apparently helped a lot of students get situated in graduate system type jobs and so forth.
Is that true?
That is certainly true.
I've talked with him a number.
He said he did tremendous labor by helping them get situated.
Then you finished up your master's science degree in the summer of 1934.
It took you one year to teach.
It took me 12 months.
You were teaching half-time while you were doing that.
What were you teaching in graduate school?
I taught what we called engineering problems.
It was then a required course for freshmen.
For freshmen, yes.
What were some of your experiences as a graduate teaching assistant in the 1930s?
Oh, it was a pleasant, challenging work.
It was methodical.
It was teaching and reading the paper.
It was the only part of it that wasn't a real pleasure.
I've always been able to work and made a great paper.
There's more than just a few.
What was the subject of your master's thesis?
The subject of my master's thesis was kill drying certain Texas hardwood for cabinet use.
Why must you search it?
I worked on it about one season.
actually we had a kill and we were getting this post oak lumber and walnut and some more local lumbers and we had to kill dry that and the question was how to kill dry it.

And we experimentally took the thing on as not only a project to kill dry the wood, but to control the conditions within the kiln so that you had an increasing temperature and an increasing relative humidity in the kiln.
And if you didn't control it just right, this post-oak will turn blue.
turned into a material that is so hard that you're running, you're running saw just to cut a piece of board in two.
What did you do after you completed your master's science degree?
I went to work with the Gulf Oil, Gulf Oil Refinery in Fort Hoffa.
That was in 1944, right.
How did you happen to find a job somewhere in the family?
Well, with a master's degree and the jobs, we were getting to open up a little bit.
And I had some sum of $100 a month while they employed us.
So you weren't there for seven years?
No.
I worked there about a year and a half.
Where was this?
Port Arthur.
Port Arthur.
What happened after that?
In contrast with that, see, I'd kept up my commission in the reserves.
And I was just on the verge of promotion to first lieutenant.
The first lieutenant got $173 and some cents with pay and allowances.
And that contrasted considerably with my $100 salary, which they were holding.
And they were going to give raises, but they never had to get around to it.
Yeah, that was 1935.
I went on active duty with the Army in command of a Civilian Conservation Corps camp.
Well, I was first over near Rusk, and then I was over in Milam.
Milam is where I commanded you.
The CCC, it happened, was a real fortunate thing for the country, outside of two or three reasons.
One was it took a bunch of young men who were unemployed otherwise, I'm not talking about
the reserve officers and all that commanded them, but it applied to them too.

But the rank and file of the trainees in the CCC camp were young men who went in there and they learned how to drive trucks, they learned how to drive bulldozers, they learned how to make roads, build fences, do all sorts of things, and they learned how to cook, make,
be an incumbent clerk, and each one of those things, in effect, made a cadre of people who were available for the United States Army, not by direct transfer, but by individual transfer.
When World War II came along, along about that same time, our standing army was 125,000.
now a million and a quarter or more.
Had it not been for a reserve cadre of people out of the CCC camp, which was nearly triple the size of the standing army, we couldn't have mobilized the force if we did it nearly so quickly.
Those camps all had a definite mission.
Some of them were forest camps, reforestation.
They would go in and make roads through the forest to serve for transportation and also for fire lanes.

and they built watchtowers for lookout towers for fires and did some actual reforestation and they then they had camps that uh some of them uh well you take up here to fort parker and uh just this side of my ham
They went in there and built a state park.
They built a dam on the Navasota River, and there's a big lake in there now, a recreation facility, and all the camp, places you can go and camp.
It's a recreation facility, a good big one.
There are others that were soil conservation camps.
They went in and actually did the terracing, did the survey work, the terracing and whatnot to make maximum use of rainfall and control soil erosion.
And a good many others.
They were all in there for a definite purpose, and they were...
The public didn't resent those at all.
And there was enough discipline.
Those boys went out and actually worked.
In those days, when a man worked, he worked.
We hear impressions of Franklin Roosevelt.
Much better then than now.
I found later that some of the big improvements that he made in the banking facilities, you know, banks all went broke.
Not all of them, but a great number of banks went broke.
They closed the doors and all back in the Great Depression.
A great many of those big improvements were actually the fruits of Herbert Hoover.

President Hoover had a great many of those things going, but when Franklin Roosevelt became president, the furthest thing in the action there was to give credit to the prior administration, which had been Republican.
And the other thing is that under the Roosevelt administration, socialism began in this country as never before, and it's still going.
One is this business of make work by the government.
Fortunately, in those days, the country was in a mood where when you made some work by the people who worked, and the WPA worked, it was far less efficient than the CCC.
But nonetheless, they did some good jobs.
But it came into the fact that it got out of the way, the fact that a person
Each man was an individual, each circumstance was an individual circumstance, and the government was obliged to go in and take care of everybody.
It has gradually progressed until people are not permitted to be poor, if you know what I mean.
I believe the good book says the poor shall inherit the earth,
They certainly have, but in contrast, they're why it's got to the point now that if they get enough handouts, they won't work.
You're not about to hire a fellow on a menial job who's on this welfare kick.
You might lose it.
In retrospect, do you think that Pergator got a bum rap from the Depression?
To a considerable extent, yes.
Do you think that Roosevelt took credit for things that he really possibly wasn't responsible for?
That's true.
Now, I'm not saying he didn't do a lot of good things.
He did, here and here.
And some of the things that Hoover was not able to legislate for the simple fact that he didn't have a majority in Congress.
Why, Roosevelt got in there, and bingo, why, banks closing and everything happening there, why, he could get most anything through Congress.
Do you remember the elections of 32 and 36?
I do.
After you left the CCC town, what did you proceed to do?
I went to work with the George G. Fix Company in Dallas.
In Dallas?
No, the name of the company.
What type of company was that?
Correction.
Is there?
Correction.
That's my second job.
The first job I got was one of adjusting automobile insurance claims for General Motors.
Where?
in the southwest region, Texas.
I was in Houston, Nacogdoches, Corpus Christi,
And I worked through this territory.
How long did you go back?
About a year and a half.
And then you went to the fixed company?
And then I went to the fixed company.
I want to get back to engineering.
Okay.
That's what I was trying to do.
Okay.
It is an engineering company.
Is it still in existence?
Yes.
What type of engineering work did you do?
I was doing sales engineering on mechanical power transmission equipment.
What was the money you made from those?
Chains.
Both V-belts, couplings, bearings, belts.
I mentioned V-belts.
You were selling these to Cummings.
Yes.
It was a sale.
And more often than not, you had to go out and tell a man what he needed because he was there ready to buy, but he didn't know what he needed to buy.
He didn't really know what he needed to buy, so you had an engineering project right there free for nothing.
But nonetheless, if you were going to sell merchandise, you had to sell him the correct merchandise, and then you gradually build up on it.
And you went to Dix County from 38 to 41?
No, I was from 37, I'd say.
I guess about 37 there until about 39.
Then what?
I came back here and they got me to working part-time on A&M.
I came back here and my father-in-law, who was an attorney, I married in 1935.
I was working in Port Arthur, but I came up here to marry.
My father-in-law was an attorney.
He was an attorney here, and he was an attorney and a surveyor.
It was a combination.
People did a lot of things in those days.
And he had a flock of surveying that people wanted done, and he couldn't possibly do it all himself.
He said, if you'll just stay here, you can work indefinitely.
So I came back in, I worked indefinitely for Spell, and it turned out after a while that my main client was A&M.
And come the fall, come the summer of 1940,
Professor Crawford said, we need, we need you as a teacher out here to come back and join us full time.
So I did.
Been there until 1967 with military service in World War II.
Right.
Okay.
And four years of working with A&M over in once and a half Bangladesh.

These Pakistanis, through the foreign aid program, they got universities in Texas or in the United States to contract with universities in foreign countries to go in there and help them to upgrade their program and just generally aid, coordinate, whatever you could with them.
And Texas A&M had a contract with the universities over in what was then East Pakistan.
It's now Bangladesh.
They had a war of separation over there.
So I was over there from 1948 to 19... 1944 to 1948 as part of A&M State.
Okay.
You were at 8 a.m. from 40 to 42, and then you left with the armed forces.
I was here one year, from 40 to 41, and then I went to the armed forces.
You went to the armed forces before Pearl Harbor, right?
What was the service that you were entering on?
I got a nice little order instead of a draft.
Oh, I was just ordered back to duty.
Okay.
Fort Monmouth, I had been in the field artillery, but they decided, that little order I got decided I was in the signal corps.
So, I was in Fort Monmouth, New Jersey.
I was there for about
Went up there to school, and they put me on the duty station.
And then they took me off of that and put me back to school.
And then when Pearl Harbor came, I got ordered to Port of Embarkation in San Francisco, and they didn't want me to ever run to port.
I was right at Pearl Harbor.
And I was in the China, Burma, India theater.
and what you did was the nature of your service.
I was in command of, first, the fixed station radio communication.
And then there was a team, and then there was a bunch of those teams that were thrown together and made into the signal service battalion, and I inherited the command of that.
And that was, that was a highlight of, I was over 31 months in that foreign service there.
You were discharged at 4 o'clock?
Yeah.
You came back at 8 a.m. and you entered this, uh...
I came back from overseas in 1944 and spent my last nine months.
I went to advanced signal school in Fort Montenegro.
I got ordered to Nashville, Tennessee, the Affair General Hospital.
T-H-A-Y-E-R.
It was a 3,500-bed hospital that they were bringing people back to overseas.
And after they began reduction in forces, well, I had my
I'm trying to hang on, and I didn't want to hang on, so I came back to A&M while the time was good.
When we were ordered to active duty, we didn't actually get a leave of absence that was expressed.
It was implied, but when they needed me, I got busy and came back.
Well, that was in 45, 45, 46.
So that was the spring of 46 was my first semester to teach after the war service.
And then I went from 46 on until 1954, before that four years of augmentation.
But, uh, how are you able to send to my location?
Well, I've been over in that area in World War II, and they asked me if I would go back over there since I was familiar with the customs.
And the general situation needed someone of the qualifications that it seemed I had.
So we carried on with it.
Did your wife want you to go?
Well, she went with me.
She went with me those four years.
Well, to me it had become a routine thing.
To her it was.
She went through the cultural shock and
Now we talk freely about what goes on over there, and before, I had the experience, and she couldn't, because you can't conceive, really.

You see a lot of stuff on the TV, you know, but you can't really conceive the conditions and the people and how they exist and the difference between the ordinary people and the educated people and the government, the politicians.
You've got three different levels.
Common, poor people.
Then you've got the ordinary people that are educated, middle-class people, and some of them are high-class, too.
And then you've got the government bureaucrats or the autocrats, in this case might be the politicians.
So when you see something on the news about Bangladesh, do you know more about it than comes to the other person around your house?
Well, some truth.
Do you have any problem with the language?
We're talking English.
I learned a little of the language.
I learned a little of the language when I was over there in World War II.
What?
No, you've got many languages over there.
Bengali is the language of some hundred million people in that general area.
People who speak Bengali, they don't have too much overlap between that and people who speak Hindi, or the people who speak Urdu, or the people who...
When I was there in World War II, the money was in the British India.
British India, which didn't include all of the areas, it included the bulk of them.
The money they had was in groupie notes.
A little note, one rupee note was small.
Five rupees was a little bigger.
Ten rupees was bigger.
Twenty rupees was still bigger.
A hundred rupees would be like bed sheets.
Everything bigger than a one rupee note had eight written languages on it.
There's eight written languages.
Now here's some 400 dilators scattered all over.
What did she exactly do?
I taught classes, and I consulted with the principal, who was the same as the president of the institution, and with the head of the mechanical engineering department.
We helped provide for them some particular pieces of equipment, some literature.
I wrote one book while I was there, and one more.
on engineering problems.
And the idea was to get an elementary book in there that would bring together to a more or less common foundation a diversity of backgrounds that these students had who got there.
Some of them were ready to go ahead with a little bit higher work, and some of them were not.
The bulk of them needed to, the education, the higher education, they were in English, in engineering, and still is.
And they couldn't speak and handle the language well enough to get on with it.
They needed some elementary, fundamental problems where you come down to what's given, what's required,
and present the solution in an orderly, step-by-step fashion.
A&M was involved in that because A&M was one of the land grant institutions.
We were recognized to have a substantial engineering and agricultural
capability and it's in those two prime areas that they were helping these countries so-called third world countries and you came back
We have one son.
And the year we went over there, he was a freshman at A&M, and he stayed here and went through his freshman year.
Then he had ambition to go over there too, so he went over there and attended college.
He didn't credit for it, but he attended college for the better part of a year and took courses and went to the University of Dhaka.
And then he came back here and went on to graduate at the A&M University.
Okay, you came back in 58.
You were associate professor of mechanical engineering when you came back.
And you held that position until you retired in 1979.
What type of research did you do in 58, 57, and 68?
I did not do direct research.
I was always loaded with guilt on teaching.
And in addition to teaching here, the last nine months, I mean the last nine semesters that I've taught extension courses down at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio.
You taught engineering problems or what else?
Oh, I taught 28 different courses, I think.
Did you teach all the undergraduates or graduates as well?
I taught some graduate work.
What were some of the changes that occurred at A&M when you came back from 58 into retirement in 76?
Well, one of them was moving over to the new building from old Fermion Hall.
You remember Fermion?
You know where the industrial, the engineering technology offices are there now?
You mean shops?
Well, see, we had, that was the Fermier Building.
Professor Fermier was one time the head, way back there, the head of the Mechanical Engineering Department.
And after his death, that building was completed and named it for himself.
F-E-R-M-I-E-R.
Sometime after that, they completed the shop building.

He was actually a great man and a great builder, and they put up the buildings in his time, and there was a lot of progress in mechanical engineering in that time, and they named the building for him.
The shop building has never been named for anybody.
I'm seeing changes in two directions.
One is good and one is bad.
The bad feature is that students
not as serious as they used to be.

Too many of them are pouring with a silver spoon in their mouth, and the old work ethic is not properly ingrained into them now that they get to college, and they're just a bunch of kids still in school.
And the best students we ever had were those right after World War II that had been in the service.
They called them GIs.

And the GI student came back, and he had his hard knocks, and he had seen the difference between the officer rank and the enlisted rank, the difference in pay, and a lot of them had all gone out and got jobs in industry, and they saw the difference between them.
and the bosses and the people and the workers.
And they were downright, and they also were a few years older than the others.
And the seriousness they had made them be the best students that we ever had.
I've heard several of the things that I'm taught to say to that class of 46 and 47 were,
It was the best I'd ever seen.
46, 47, it extended right on up to...
It sort of phased out, but that extended on up to about, oh, in the early 50s.
I'd say in the matter of 53, we still were getting a lot of so-called GIs.
We were getting them then that had been out working more, and some of them stayed in the Army a little bit longer.
We had good students then, and they were not writer's students, but they were more diligent.
Kind of like football, you know, you take an ordinary player who's got his heart set to do a job,
You come a whole lot nearer to getting it done than some fellow that's got all sorts of ability and only half-hearted and half-professional.
What about the changes that occur as a result of the Corps being made voluntary?
You see, that effect on the university as well.
That change, unfortunately or unfortunately as it may be,
There's good and there's bad in that.
I was part of the old army gang where everybody was required to be in there and I've seen, I've taught on through the time when only a quarter of the people were in the Corps.
And the Corps is not for everybody and everybody's not for the Corps.
If you take a fellow who has a disdain for the military, why, the Corps shouldn't have to put up with you.
On the other hand, the training and discipline they get in the Corps is certainly a thing that has given Texas A&M graduates a reputation for
personnel management, being able to get along with people and do things.
But A&M has given a real reputation that the people from liberal arts schools or the schools that did not have military never got.
Now, that period of change happened to coincide with the period of the 60s.
in which you had all the Vietnam draft dodges, and all of the burning of the ROTCs in not A&M, thank goodness, but in Facebook, Columbia, you name it.
A lot of those places where they went in and literally set fire to the ROTC buildings and did other damage.
had all their parades.
They did their thing out at Berkeley.
And to the extent that that exists, why, I'd say the non-military is a bane on the, it's a bane on democracy.
